stream_context.summary: Kaze works on 'Course 14', a level with a craft materials and diorama theme. The stream focuses on solving major design challenges for the level's environment, specifically creating a background, a death-floor, and a horizon that are both thematically appropriate and technically feasible on the N64. He also openly discusses his YouTube content strategy with his viewers.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a 'fake normal map' using a cheap rim lighting effect on the background to simulate the shine of wet paint, a key aesthetic breakthrough for the level.
development_findings.quote: Shall I add a fake normal map to this? So that when you turn the camera, there's like highlights like this moving. Oh, that would look so good.

development_findings.summary: A core design challenge for the craft level is creating a death floor that doesn't look like a walkable surface, leading Kaze to reject a 'desk' theme and experiment with paper 'water'.
development_findings.quote: I want there to be a death floor. So maybe we need to innovate a different way to make a death floor look.

development_findings.summary: The project is on Course 14 out of 15, with Course 15 halfway complete. The overworld, Bowser level, and other side levels are still outstanding.
Kaze concluded that a simple 2D image for the background was insufficient, leading him to build a 3D cylindrical background to create a more immersive diorama effect.
development_findings.quote: I think the problem is the image itself. I don't think a 2D image as a background ever works here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze frequently evaluates ideas based on their performance cost on N64 hardware, rejecting concepts like a floor made of cotton balls as too high-poly.
development_findings.quote: The problem is, cotton balls at the entire bottom, that's gonna be so high poly, isn't it? How are we gonna do that without insane amount of lag?

development_findings.summary: To solve the ugly seam between the paper 'water' floor and the cylindrical walls, Kaze decided to build a full cardboard mountain range and programmatically cut the floor geometry to hide the intersection.
Kaze decided to place the entire craft level diorama inside an 'infinitely far' background model of a room resembling a Toad House to create a final, contained environment.

Kaze identified a new performance bottleneck in the engine, shifting from memory throughput to the RSP (Reality Signal Processor), but feels he needs more information from contributor Sauraen before he can confidently discuss it.
Planned mechanics and elements for Course 14 include glue patches that slow Mario, moving scissor enemies, pipe cleaner Goombas, and a ruler that acts as a trampoline.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views his YouTube channel as his job, which funds the game development, which he considers the 'fun part'.
context_findings.quote: For me, YouTube at this point is the job part and like making the game is the fun part.

context_findings.summary: Kaze actively avoids using materials from the Nintendo 'Giga Leak' out of fear of legal repercussions from Nintendo, who he feels are already targeting his channel.
context_findings.quote: I on purpose stayed away from the giga league as much as I could because I figured if I ever look at the giga league and do content with it they're gonna completely murder me because they are already murdering my youtube channel whenever I can.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes Paper Mario: The Origami King was a failed experiment by Nintendo to create a game driven purely by gameplay without extrinsic motivation like an RPG system.
context_findings.quote: The entire game just exists for you to play it for the sake of playing it. And it failed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy for the craft level is that it should look like a finished diorama, not a work-in-progress, rejecting ideas that break that immersion.
context_findings.quote: I want this to look like someone put this together and then was done with that's why i was opposed to having the stick of glue lying around here too.

context_findings.summary: Kaze openly discusses his YouTube content strategy with his audience, listing over a dozen potential video ideas and asking for their input.
He is annoyed by the common fan defense of Nintendo's past development limitations, stating he gets many comments like 'but Kaze it was 1996' when he is critical of a design decision.
Kaze is going back to his day job in a few days, indicating that the game development and YouTube content creation are not yet his full-time occupation.

biobak.summary: Biobak is currently working on the remake of Course 1, which Kaze wants to include in the demo.
Biobak provided the core concept for the background of Course 14: a large paper cylinder with drawings on it, which Kaze adopted and built upon.
biobak.quote: Biobak was suggesting that there would be like... That this whole thing would be inside a paper cylinder. And the paper cylinder is gonna have stuff drawn onto it.

zeina.summary: Zeina (referred to as 'Eiza') collaborated with Kaze on a 'slide deck' for Course 15, which conceptualized the assets and allowed Kaze to pre-program them.
zeina.quote: But quest 15 is also already halfway done because I already programmed all the assets for it, for the slide deck I made with Eiza.

key_stories.title: Designing the Craft Level Diorama
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to design the background and floor for the craft-themed Course 14. He wanted a contained 'diorama' feel but needed a clear death boundary. Through experimentation and a breakthrough 'shiny paint' effect, he created a 3D paper cylinder background and a 'water' floor made of gift wrap.
key_stories.challenge: The craft level needed a background that felt immersive and contained, with a death floor that players wouldn't mistake for a safe, walkable surface.
key_stories.process: Kaze started with Biobak's concept of a paper cylinder. He rejected using a desk as the setting. He experimented with various textures for the background and floor, including cobblestone and construction paper. A key moment was his idea to implement a 'fake normal map' to make the painted background look shiny, which he successfully coded as a cheap rim-lighting effect.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a 3D cylindrical background of painted paper with a custom 'shiny' lighting effect and a taped seam. For the floor, he created a 'water' effect out of gift wrap paper, solving the death floor problem thematically.
key_stories.key_quote: I want this to look like it's placed on a desk or something. But I can't have a desk be the actual background, so this puts me in a bit of a weird situation.

key_stories.title: Solving the Horizon Problem
key_stories.summary: The floor and walls of the craft level didn't connect cleanly, creating visual bugs. Kaze's solution was to build a complete cardboard mountain range around the edge of the level, which would allow him to cut the floor geometry short, hiding the problematic seam entirely.
key_stories.challenge: The 'water' floor, made of paper, had a visually jarring and technically problematic seam where it met the cylindrical background walls, causing Z-fighting.
key_stories.process: After creating the paper floor and cylindrical walls, Kaze immediately noticed the ugly intersection. He placed some individual mountain models, but they clipped through the floor. After considering the problem, he realized that instead of trying to blend the two surfaces, he could use a new foreground element (the mountain range) to completely obscure the problem area.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided that the definitive solution was to model a full, continuous mountain range around the level's perimeter and then programmatically cut the floor's geometry so it terminates just before the mountains, completely hiding the seam.
key_stories.key_quote: If I can make a full mountain range I could probably just cut that right before it reaches the mountain and no one would ever find out.
